DOC.HEAD: Watkins Says Arms Plants Might Need Health-Protection Changes
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department is considering whether to modify its nuclear weapons plants in response to a report that exposure to low-level radiation may carry more cancer risk than previously believed. A National Research Council committee said in a report this week that exposure to low-level radiation poses a cancer risk three to four times greater than previously thought. Many workers in the 17 major weapons facilities work with equipment that emit low-level radiation, and recent government reports on plants in Ohio, Colorado, Tennessee and Texas said workers have too little protection from radiation exposure. On Thursday, the department released copies of a memorandum from Energy Secretary James D. Watkins ordering his acting assistant secretary for environment, safety and health, Peter N. Brush, to assess the implications of the radiation study for the weapons program. ``Your report should include recommended options for modifying operations where such changes appear warranted,'' Watkins wrote in the memo dated Wednesday. He did not indicate whether he believed any changes would be necessary. Watkins asked for an interim report within 90 days and a final report by June 30, 1990. The National Research Council committee used new methods of estimating and assessing the health effects of radiation, and it concluded that a 1980 study by another NRC committee significantly underestimated the cancer risk from low-level radiation. The risk for solid tumor cancer is three times greater than the earlier estimate, and the risk from leukemia is four times greater, the committee concluded. And the committee found a much greater danger for mental retardation among unborn babies exposed to low-level radiation from the eighth to 15th weeks after conception. Its study was based partly on the medical history of 76,000 survivors of the 1945 atomic bombings in Japan, health studies of workers at nuclear facilities and the records of patients treated with X-rays for certain medical conditions. In a separate report released Wednesday, another NRC committee said past and current releases of radiation from the nuclear weapons plants appear to be too low to have caused any significant increase in risk to public health. It added, however, that the Energy Department should do more to study the health effects.
